title: Linear Approximation Function
text: Use the following equation $$L(x)=f{\left(a\right)}+\operatorname{f'}\left(a\right) \left(x-a\right)$$ to make a linear approximation, where f(a) is the function and f'(a) is the derivative of the function.

title: Taking the Derivative of f(x) to Get f'(x)
text: The next step is finding f'(x) by taking the derivative of f(x) $$=$$ $${sin}^2 x$$. By using the chain rule $$F'(x)=f'(g(x))(g'(x))$$, we first take the derivative of the outer function such that $$\frac{d}{dx} u^2$$ $$=$$ 2u. Next, we take the derivative of the inner function where $$\frac{d}{dx} \operatorname{sinx}\left(x\right)$$ $$=$$ cos(x). Lastly, we combine the two steps through multiplication to get $$\frac{d}{dx} {sin}^2 x$$ $$=$$ f'(x) $$=$$ $$2u cos\left(x\right)$$ $$=$$ 2sin(x)cos(x).
